DOC.HEAD: Bomb Squad Dispatched to Stars' Home After Movie Prop Found
DOC.TEXT: Sheriff's deputies responding to a call at a house owned by actors Bryan Brown and Rachel Ward discovered that the bombs used in movies look just like the real thing. The Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department said Sunday the fake bomb was discovered after a man called from Australia to ask if deputies could check on his ex-wife and daughter, who were living in the house. Authorities said the woman, who was not identified, rents the house from Brown and Ward. Upon their arrival at the house Saturday, deputies saw in the garage what looked like four sticks of dynamite connected to a timer. ``Arson-explosives personnel responded and confirmed that it was a movie prop,'' said Sgt. Mark Dailey. ``It ended up being empty tubes stuffed with newspaper,'' said Deputy Steven Wilson. ``But it had all the right markings and it was the right shape and color.'' He added that the device looked so real the bomb squad decided to confiscate it. Similar props were used in the 1986 movie ``F-X,'' in which Brown played a special-effects expert who used smoke bombs, fake blood and dummies to elude pursuers. Miss Ward, who is Brown's wife, has appeared in such films as ``Dead Men Don't Wear Plaid'' and ``Sharkey's Machine.''
